narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Great foundational information about present neuroscience research methods and the history / development / advances in science that led to those methods. In particular, this course relies heavily on physics to explain imaging methods but the explanation and presentation of those concepts was clear (I have no background in physics)

Practical knowledge about various acquisition techniques in human neuroscience: neuroimaging, electrophysiological recordings, brain stimulation, optical imaging. Some discussion of statistical analysis and ethical issues/publication bias.
Research methods. Very helpful. Would advise to take before research

- basic understanding and facility with a great variety of human neuroscience techniques, their ethical and statistical implications, and how multiple techniques can be marshaled into an effective experimental design
The course taught me a lot about the different methods of how to visualize the human Brain.
I learned many research methods in Human Neuroscience, such as EEG, MEG, MRI, fMRI, PET, EROS,. Helpful methods.
Study skills
Survey course of neuroscience research methods, such as fMRI, PET, NIRS, EEG, etc.

This class taught me immense knowledge that prepares me for research projects (such as a thesis project and beyond), and it was instrumental in teaching me to think like a scientist -- evaluating the various details of an experimental questions to determine the proper procedure and methods to employ.
Research methods in neuroscience and current research papers
I learned the applications of imaging within neuroscience.
Topics about imaging the brain
I learned how PET, MRI, EEG, and other neuroimaging techniques work
I learned a lot about a variety of neuroscience techniques to examine brain activity and structures.

The main takeaway from this course (so far as I can tell) is that discoveries in neuroscience (and in many other scientific fields) are generally preceded by technological advancements. The course is about understanding not only how imaging technology works (from the perspective of physics), but also about how the refinement of imaging technology has helped advance the field.

I gained a lot of knowledge on the host of research methods which are used in human neuroscience. I learned how to organize information in a logical way in my studying and when taking exams. I learned how to design an experiment and think about which methods apply when asking certain questions about brain structure and function.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths -- Prof McCarthy is really really good at explaining concepts and provides lots of supplementary material and written answers to questions online. 
Having the textbook as a background was helpful although admittedly I did not read it. 
The course was overall well organized in terms of the order that material was presented and tying concepts together.

Weaknesses -- I'm not sure how it could be improved, but the only grade in the course were based on written examinations. The exams were fair and reflective of the material covered and discussed in class, but some period recap and other grade might also be helpful -- especially since the second exam required a lot of writing and not quite enough time to do it all.

Prof. McCarthy is a very good lecturer! He explains complex topics very well and often prompts us to arrive at solutions in intuitive ways. He also holds really helpful and in-depth review sessions before exams and is very responsive on Ed discussion. Another strength for me is that the content was all very practical, compared to many other classes I have taken in psych/cogsci departments. A weakness is that your entire grade is 3 exams, which is stressful. The exams are fair but long.
Would have been nice to see live demos and do trips to the medical school

strengths: 
- lectures were well paced and concepts were very clearly explained
- instructor was extremely responsive on Ed Discussion
- review sessions were very helpful 
- I think the exams were overall pretty fair

weakness: 
- I understand that the professor has past videos that are helpful to look back at to understand concepts such as undersampling and signal averaging, but I feel like we could have taken more time to walk through these difficult concepts together in class
Sometimes the content is a lot in terms of the total amount of information you learn in a single class. But I feel the assessments were fair in checking for comprehension of key ideas.

The material was very applicable to psychology - neuro track and neuroscience majors, but the class was a bit challenging to follow and the assessments were very hard. I think a more consistent assessment method would have been helpful.

I liked the lectures, but they could be a bit too slow for me. This course should have sections for students to engage with the material beyond lectures. It is difficult material. More options to review could be helpful. Having a portion of the course that rehashes specific content that is assumed knowledge would be incredibly helpful.
No weaknesses.
More assignments would be better

Strengths: Not having homework was nice
Weaknesses: I wish there could be little quizzes throughout the semester, or something else to help break up the grade, also, this course can get pretty technical, so having a physics background would be helpful.

I thought the class was very well organized, and there were many resources available for help. I think that some of the lectures moved quickly or incorporated concepts that we were not necessarily prepared for. However, Professor McCarthy did a great job explaining these when asked.
strong: very comprehensive it was a good deal of work
Strengths: definitely gave me a good foundation on imaging techniques and practical experimentation
Grading schema is such a weakness. There is no way to improve in the class because the grades are all determined by exams

Prof. McCarthy is an experienced teacher and he knows what he is doing. The only improvement I personally would recommend is to switch from only 3 exam and nothing else assessment format to something which integrates a weekly/biweekly check (can be something small like pass/fail quizzes to something more intense like Human Brain qset format)

This was a content-rich lecture style course that did a great job clearly explaining the methods discussed. I would have liked weekly assignments to help solidify information and understand it better. Basing the entire grade off of 3 exams does not fairly assess what students understand about the material, as they might not remember the specifics of a certain experiment discussed in class but they can understand how it works. Also, I did not like having to schedule a meeting with the TA to see my exam answers because it was inconvenient and I did not particularly want to discuss any aspects of my score -- I just wanted to see where marks were taken.
I think the lectures are very formative, you can tell the professor enjoys teaching the content. I loved the review sessions before the exams, they were very helpful.

I really love the content of this course. The information is engaging and also helps provide an important foundation for anyone in the neuroscience major. I actually think it should be a foundational class for the major because it really helps you understand the basis of so many important methods.  I really liked the exams and structure of the class. However, I do think that the class could have a few more assignments to keep students engaged in the material and encourage continuous learning rather than cramming before exams which I often fell into (and recognize is often my own fault).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Everyone interested in Human Neuroscience should take this course.

Great course if you are Psych / Neuro and a junior, or a senior planning to continue working in human brain research and will need a basis of research methods. (basically if senior spring and not continuing in the field it might not be worth it)
It was great for me to tie together what I am starting to do in lab with what is going on / has been done historically in the field.

Since the only grades are exams, it is worth it to recap and review notes as you go to prevent cramming.

Yes, Prof. McCarthy is an excellent lecturer and presents difficult information in a very digestible manner. But the content is quite technical, so only take it if you are interested in the nitty gritty of neuroscience techniques (i.e. the underlying physics).
Yes, especially if you are planning on doing neuroscience research

yes, but really only if you are interested in applying human neuroscience techniques into your own research or you need it for your major (e.g. neuroscience major). as the name suggests, it is a rather domain-specific class and I don't think it is very broadly applicable outside of the scope of human neuroscience.
I think there are other more approachable research methods course, so I would not
If the material of the course is directly related to your future, yes. Otherwise, no need to step foot here.
Absolutely. This class was a fantastic introduction to human neuroscience methods.
Yes
If you're planning to do any sort of brain research, yes.
Yes, especially to those who have a good fundamental understanding of neuroscience and physics and are interested in pursuing Human Neuroscience research in some capacity.
yeah if you are at all interested in neuro or psych
Yes, it's a good foundation for neuroscience knowledge.
No. This is difficult. Don't take this unless you like neuroscience
Yes! Definitely take this course if you are interested in learning how neuroscience methods like fMRI or EEG work.
This was a requirement for my degree. I would not necessarily recommend for a non-major, unless you are really interested in the content. It takes a lot of effort to do well.
I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in understanding the mechanics behind brain imaging techniques.

Yes! 100%. This class was incredible and so foundational if you are studying neuroscience. It really put all of the methods into perspective and helped me feel confident reading research papers and conducting research myself. Professor McCarthy is also amazing and great at answering questions.
